thread.title_full: Moon Area, Cornell merger discussions erupt into debate at school board meeting

author: kschaeffer@timesonline.com(Katherine Schaeffer)
title: Moon Area, Cornell merger discussions erupt into debate at school board meeting
text:
Larger font size Posted: Monday, October 5, 2015 10:45 pm Moon Area, Cornell merger discussions erupt into debate at school board meeting By Katherine Schaeffer kschaeffer@timesonline.com Timesonline.com | 0 comments 
Recently revisited discussion of a potential merger between Moon Area and Cornell School Districts erupted into heated debate at Moon’s school board meeting Tuesday evening. 
Cornell superintendent Aaron Thomas publicly questioned the motive behind the merger after Moon superintendent Curt Baker outlined a plan to combine the two districts starting next fall. 
“I will always, always do the best for my kids to improve and offer them athletic, academic and artistic initiatives,” Thomas said. “But I don’t want to be used as political pawn in a game.” 
Thomas also expressed concern over Baker's suggested timeline, which would require both school boards to approve the merger before Oct. 31. 
If approved, both boards would dissolve and be overseen by the Allegheny Intermediate Unit until the next round of elections in April 2016. 
Thomas said he and Baker had not met to discuss the merger since pausing talks last September. 
Incoming board members, like Danielle Zeiger, say they believe the hasty merger’s primary objective is to dissolve Moon’s school board before the November election. The incoming board members have vocally disagreed with recent changes in the district, notably the reconfiguration of the district’s elementary schools, which resulted in Hyde Elementary's closing. 
“This three-week time frame is unprecedented for a merger,” Zeiger said, adding that districts usually conduct years of feasibility studies before committing to combine. 
The potential merger was first suggested in June 2014, during the same meeting where the board voted to close Hyde. 
Talks were put on hold in fall 2014 as Gov. Tom Wolf and state secretary of education Pedro Rivera took office. Now that the new state legislators are seated, the district felt it was appropriate to revisit talks, he said, Baker said. 
The districts have considered merging several times before, and the upcoming elections offer a unique opportunity to dissolve both school boards in preparation for a merger, Baker said. 
Blending two demographically different districts would benefit both communities, he said. 
Cornell serves students in Coraopolis and Neville Township. It is one of the smallest districts in Allegheny County, with fewer than 650 students in grades K-12. About 70 percent of students qualify for free or reduced lunch. 
Moon Area’s enrollment is just over 3,700, and district students have the opportunity to participate in a wide range of classes, sports and extracurricular activities just by virtue of the district’s size, Baker said. 
“The children coming to Moon, if you can provide them with broader opportunities and improved educational outcomes, why not do it?” Baker said. 
Monday’s presentation will be posted to Moon Area’s website, Baker said. 
The agenda for Moon’s Oct. 12 board meeting hasn’t changed, Baker said. Community members from both districts are invited to attend the meeting and participate in public comment.
